lines.text: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Give me some music music, moody food Of us that trade in love.

lines.speaker: attendants
lines.text: The music, ho!
Enter MARDIAN

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Let it alone lets to billiards: come, Charmian.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: My arm is sore best play with Mardian.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: As well a woman with an eunuch playd As with a woman. Come, youll play with me, sir

lines.speaker: mardian
lines.text: As well as I can, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: And when good will is showd, thought come too short, The actor may plead pardon. Ill none now: Give me mine angle well to the river: there, My music playing far off, I will betray Tawnyfinnd fishes my bended hook shall pierce Their slimy jaws and, as I draw them up, Ill think them every one an Antony, And say Ah, ha! youre caught.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Twas merry when You wagerd on your angling when your diver Did hang a saltfish on his hook, which he With fervency drew up.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: That time,O times! I laughd him out of patience and that night I laughd him into patience and next morn, Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst I wore his sword Philippan. O, from Italy Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears, That long time have been barren.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Madam, madam,

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Antonius dead!If thou say so, villain, Thou killst thy mistress: but well and free, If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here My bluest veins to kiss a hand that kings Have lippd, and trembled kissing.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: First, madam, he is well.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Why, theres more gold. But, sirrah, mark, we use To say the dead are well: bring it to that, The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy illuttering throat.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Good madam, hear me.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Well, go to, I will But theres no goodness in thy face: if Antony Be free and healthful,so tart a favour To trumpet such good tidings! If not well, Thou shouldst come like a Fury crownd with snakes, Not like a formal man.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Willt please you hear me

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speakst: Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well, Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him, Ill set thee in a shower of gold, and hail Rich pearls upon thee.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Madam, hes well.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Well said.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: And friends with Caesar.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Thourt an honest man.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Make thee a fortune from me.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: But yet, madam,

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I do not like But yet, it does allay The good precedence fie upon But yet! But yet is as a gaoler to bring forth Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend, Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear, The good and bad together: hes friends with Caesar: In state of health thou sayst and thou sayst free.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Free, madam! no I made no such report: Hes bound unto Octavia.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: For what good turn

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: For the best turn i the bed.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I am pale, Charmian.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Madam, hes married to Octavia.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
Strikes him down

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Good madam, patience.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: What say you Hence, Horrible villain! or Ill spurn thine eyes Like balls before me Ill unhair thy head: Thou shalt be whippd with wire, and stewd in brine, Smarting in lingering pickle.
Strikes him again
She hales him up and down

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Gracious madam, I that do bring the news made not the match.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Say tis not so, a province I will give thee, And make thy fortunes proud: the blow thou hadst Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage And I will boot thee with what gift beside Thy modesty can beg.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Hes married, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.
Draws a knife

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Nay, then Ill run. What mean you, madam I have made no fault.
Exit

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Good madam, keep yourself within yourself: The man is innocent.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Some innocents scape not the thunderbolt. Melt Egypt into Nile! and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents! Call the slave again: Though I am mad, I will not bite him: call.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: He is afeard to come.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I will not hurt him. These hands do lack nobility, that they strike A meaner than myself since I myself Have given myself the cause. Come hither, sir. Though it be honest, it is never good To bring bad news: give to a gracious message. An host of tongues but let ill tidings tell Themselves when they be felt.
Exit CHARMIAN
Reenter CHARMIAN and Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: I have done my duty.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Is he married I cannot hate thee worser than I do, If thou again say Yes.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Hes married, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: The gods confound thee! dost thou hold there still

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Should I lie, madam

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: O, I would thou didst, So half my Egypt were submerged and made A cistern for scaled snakes! Go, get thee hence: Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: I crave your highness pardon.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: He is married

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Take no offence that I would not offend you: To punish me for what you make me do. Seems much unequal: hes married to Octavia.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: O, that his fault should make a knave of thee, That art not what thourt sure of! Get thee hence: The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome Are all too dear for me: lie they upon thy hand, And be undone by em!
Exit Messenger

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Good your highness, patience.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: In praising Antony, I have dispraised Caesar.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Many times, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I am paid fort now. Lead me from hence: I faint: O Iras, Charmian! tis no matter. Go to the fellow, good Alexas bid him Report the feature of Octavia, her years, Her inclination, let him not leave out The colour of her hair: bring me word quickly. Let him for ever go:let him notCharmian, Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon, The other ways a Mars. Bid you Alexas Bring me word how tall she is. Pity me, Charmian, But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.
Exit ALEXAS
To MARDIAN
Exeunt
